name: rare earth element mine operation and beneficiation, ion adsorption clays | rare earth carbonate concentrate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22421/documentation

This dataset refers to the mining and beneficiation activities (in-situ leaching) of ion adsorption clays spreading across seven southern provinces in China (Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Yunnan, and Zhejiang) in order to produce rare earth carbonate concentrate. The produced carbonate concentrate will then undergo roasting, calcination and solvent extraction in order to produce high purity individual rare earth oxides. Compared to the other production pathways of rare earth oxides in China, this pathway produces 15 individual REOs (cerium, europium, lanthanum, neodymium, samarium, ytterbium, yttrium, dysprosium, erbium, gadolinium, holmium, lutetium, praseodymium, terbium and thulium oxide.;Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Currently, mining and processing of rare earth elements is predominantly carried out in China, where they are extracted mainly via open pit mining of bastnäsite and/or monazite deposits or the leaching of ion-adsorption clays.;Modelling approach: This dataset was created using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018).

The activity starts with the mining of the clays.

The activitity ends with the production of rare earth carbonate concentrate..

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: First discovery of the ion adsorption clay containing REEs happened in 1969 in the Jinangxi province in southern China. Later on, more deposits have been found and subsequently mined in the same region, with the most prominent of them being located in the provinces of Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Hunan, Jiangxi, Yunnan, and Zhejiang. The main cause of the formation of these deposits is the in‐situ lateritic weath-ering of rare‐earth rich host rocks, forming over the course of geological times aluminosilicate clays.  These formed clays can adsorb lanthanide ions that are either released or dissolved, during this geo-logical process, which occur ideally under subtropical climates, making the Southern provinces of China the best paradigm. Ion-adsorption clays deposits from South China usually contain 0.04−0.25% REOs.;Source: Papangelakis, V. G., & Moldoveanu, G. (2014). Recovery of rare earth elements from clay minerals. Paper presented at the Proceedings of the 1st Rare Earth Resources Conference, Milos.;;
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Ion-adsorption clays deposits from South China usually contain 0.04−0.25% REOs. Despite their low concentra-tion and reserves, increased production of REEs from these deposits has been reported over the last 10 years, due to easiness of mining and concentrating through through the use of weak acids. For this reason, in-situ leaching has become the prominent method for REE extraction from ion adsorption clays. Ammonium sulfate is used in order to leach the ion adsorption clays, with the precipitation of the leachate occurring through the use of ammonium bicarbonate or oxalic acid. The resulting carbonate concentrate contains approximately 45% REOs.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is based on the following publication: Arshi, P. S., Vahidi, E., & Zhao, F. (2018). Behind the Scenes of Clean Energy: The Environmental Footprint of Rare Earth Products. ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering, 6(3), 3311-3320. doi:10.1021/acssuschemeng.7b03484.   
All exchanges from/ to the environment and from/to the technosphere were calculated using the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university. This excel-based software acts as a supporting tool to the abovementioned publication. Individual exchanges such as sulfidic tailings and wastewater which were not contained in the original datasets have been added for completness purposes and their calculation is based on mass balance.

flow.name: rare earth carbonate concentrate
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

exchanges.description: Value taken from the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure) and corresponds to the production of 1 kg of rare earth carbonate concentrate.

exchanges.description: Value taken from the critical materials life cycle assessment tool (CMLCAT) of Arshi et al. (2018), provided by F. Zhao from Purdue university (more information on the sampling procedure) and corresponds to the production of 1 kg of rare earth carbonate concentrate.

The calculation of the individual rare earth element (REE) content of the carbonate concentrate is based on the fact that the concentrate contains 45% mixed REE and that the per kg production of refined RE oxides from the ion adsorption clays contain 0.002 kg thulium oxide.
Input assumed for completeness purposes. Value taken from the existing dataset ''rare earth concentrate production, 70% REO, from bastnäsite, CN'' from the 3.6 version of the Ecoinvent database.

The calculation of the individual rare earth element (REE) content of the carbonate concentrate is based on the fact that the concentrate contains 45% mixed REE and that the per kg production of refined RE oxides from the ion adsorption clays contain 0.007 kg holmium oxide.
Input assumed for completeness purposes. Value taken from the existing dataset ''rare earth concentrate production, 70% REO, from bastnäsite, CN'' from the 3.6 version of the Ecoinvent database.

Ion adsorption clays contain 0.04% - 0.25% rare earth oxides (REOs). Estimation of the amount of clay extracted from the grade is based on 0.04% REO concentration. Value taken from the publication, on which this dataset is based (more information on sampling procedure).
